Comments_List: I gained a deep understanding of both archaeology and the study of ancient civilizations. Honestly, one of the most interesting and thought provoking classes I have taken in my time at Yale.

As someone who knew next to nothing about world religions and how they are studied through archaeology, I learned a lot, especially about the indigenous religions of South America. I also learned about how archaeologists are able to glean insight from a site or object.
I developed a much wider ranging and more nuanced understanding of the importance of considering religious thought and behavior in interpreting past behavior. This class was highly valuable to me.

The main strength of the class is Professor Burger's engagement with the material and great knowledge about the topic. He is able to discuss anything we study in the class at length, and is clearly an expert in his field. He has a wealth of fascinating and humorous anecdotes about his fieldwork that he is happy to share with the class. The readings he picked for us were all interesting and relevant. The assignments were a pleasure to complete, as they involved going to religious sites and putting ourselves in the shoes of archaeologists. The main weakness is we received no feedback on our papers, not even grades.

Yes, I took the class as an undergraduate in a dual listed class. It was extremely interesting to take the class with grad students who have a deep and profound understanding of the course material. Professor Burger was an amazing discussion leader. Overall a really amazing class.
I would recommend this course to, quite literally, anyone at Yale. Very interesting subject matter, fantastic professor, not an unreasonable amount of work.
